# BEST COFEE SHOPS IN SAN FRANCISCO

There is no shortage of phenomenal coffee shops in the San Francisco Bay Area. As a self-proclaimed coffee connoisseur, I've had my fair share of cups in the city. Whether you're searching for a place to sit down and catch up with a friend or looking to taste the best third-wave coffee the city has to offer, there's something for everyone on this list of the best coffee shops in San Francisco.

## **Andytown Coffee Roasters**

There's always a lineup at this cozy, contemporary coffee shop in the Outer Sunset. And for good reason! Known best for the famous Snowy Plover, a refreshing coffee float made with espresso, Pellegrino and the most delicious homemade whipped cream I've ever tasted!

## **Blue Bottle Coffee**

With a focus on single origin beans, Blue Bottle Coffee is considered one of the most knowledgable and skillful coffee roasters in the third wave coffee game. With cafes in LA, SF, NYC, & Japan, their fresh and flavorful roasts are carefully sourced and treated with care to produce a premium product. My favorite Blue Bottle location to visit is the one inside the San Francisco Ferry Building! *Hot Tip: Order a Liege waffle and enjoy your coffee with a gorgeous view of the Bay Bridge - you can't go wrong!*

## **Cafe Réveille**

Cafe Réveille started out as a single Coffee Truck in Jackson Square, now with multiple cafes across the Bay Area. Their Mission Bay location offers a charming spot to sit down and enjoy your coffee outdoors on one of their pretty pink table tops! Their brunch menu is delicious AF and rotates occasionally.

## **Flywheel Coffee Roasters**

Located in Haight-Ashbury, Flywheel is hands-down one of the best coffee shops in San Francisco. An independent specialty coffee roaster, they offer a variety of hand crafted methods including siphon, cold brew and nitro to name a few. The baristas are friendly and the espresso drinks are fantastic. Grab a seat by the window and soak in the sunlight as you sip on your coffee in the industrial-style space.

## **Four Barrel Coffee**

If I *had* to pick a favorite on this list - Four Barrel would be it. An independent, locally owned coffee roastery in The Mission, where the beans (which come from third-generation farmers and mill-workers in Latin America, Indonesia, and East Africa) are roasted fresh in-house. If you want to see the roasting process in action, just grab a seat at the back bar and watch them work their magic! Giving each cup the attention it deserves, you'll find that Four Barrel's baristas are friendly, efficient and consistent. The espresso is always smooth, indicating a carefully extracted espresso shot, and the latte art is well-executed. It’s the smoothest cup you’ll find in the Bay Area (IMHO) and it's easy to come often and stay awhile. Read more about Four Barrel [here](https://www.sugarandstamps.com/blog/four-barrel-coffee). ***PS:*** *You can also find Four Barrel Coffee served at San Francisco favorites like Dynamo Donut or The Mill to enjoy alongside some tasty pastries!*

## **Hollow (Temporarily Closed)**

This hidden gem has a beautiful outdoor space where you can sip their delicious, gourmet coffee. Located in Inner Sunset, I discovered this spot while strolling around the neighborhood (post-Dynamo Donut) and enjoyed my time at this cozy cafe.

## **Home Cafe**

If you're looking for the most unique and flavorful lattes in San Francisco, look no further than Home Cafe. This spot is perfect place to start off your weekend. Where else can you get such an assortment of lattes and creative toast options?! Though I much prefer my coffee without any added sugar, I love treating myself to their famous birthday cake latte, even when it’s not my birthday!

## **LINEA CAFFE**

This cute little corner caffe & eco-friendly espresso bar is located in The Mission and quickly became a favorite of mine. The espresso is smooth as can be and their almond milk is steamed to perfection. I’ve been back many times and they never disappoint! Bonus points for the silky-smooth ceramic cups that give you a pop of red for your #coffeegram!

## **marigold cafe**

One of the newest spots on the map in San Francisco, Marigold is a beautiful cafe & flower shop concept. Their coffee shop is tucked behind Marigold’s flower shop on a quiet street in The Mission. Warm tones and floral bouquets adorn the space, where they serve Heart Roasters (one of my favorites from Portland), delicious seasonal drinks & a small selection of pastries. Outdoor seating is also available, perfect for catching up with a friend or reading a good book!

## **Philz Coffee**

With multiple locations across San Francisco, my go-to spot for a morning pour over is none other than Philz! Focusing on made-to-order drip coffee, this place has had my heart for a long long time. Not sure what to order? Don't worry — the baristas here are top notch. Briefly describe how you like your coffee and they’ll get you going in the right direction. **My bean preferences:** Tesora, Silken Soul (a blend of Silken Splendor & Philtered Soul), and the Mission Cold Brew!

## **Ritual Coffee Roasters**

A top contender in San Francisco's third wave coffee scene is Ritual. Ritual is a fully independent and woman-owned coffee roasting company, maintaining the highest standard for quality and sustainable sourcing in the industry. The flagship cafe on Valencia Street first opened in 2005, and Ritual now has cafes throughout the city as well as in Napa and the Harvey Milk Terminal (1B) at SFO Airport. Consistently flavorful and aromatic coffee is what you can expect here. Learn more about Ritual [here](https://www.sugarandstamps.com/blog/ritual-coffee-roasters).

## **Saint Frank Coffee**

This swanky coffee shop nestled in Russian Hill serves quality beans in a simple and serene environment. Minimalist decor and an airy atmosphere make for a perfect space to come get some work done and sip on your coffee of choice! **PS:** Whether or not you like to opt for non-dairy, they've got a fantastic almond & macadamia nut milk that you *must* try!

## **Sightglass Coffee**

It's not just the beautiful, two-level industrial space that brings all the San Franciscans to Sightglass - the stellar coffee quality (all light roasts, BTW) is enough to keep you coming back time after time. Spend a few hours in this pretty space filled with sunlight and wooden accents, and don't forget to try something from their affogato bar at the 7th Street flagship location!

## **The COFFEE MOVEMENT**

I stumbled upon this place on a staycation in San Francisco and I’m so glad I did! Serving up great craft coffee in a cozy, well-lit space in Chinatown / Nob Hill near the Cable Car line, the gentlemen running this place are not only super friendly but also really know their stuff! Minimalist vibes, a warm interior and great dairy alternative options.

## **Wrecking Ball Coffee Roasters**

Arguably one of the best and most historic cups of coffee in the Bay Area, Wrecking Ball is serving up specialty coffee that is sustainably sourced and roasted by experts in their field. And the ever so popular pineapple wallpaper doesn't hurt either! *While you’re here, grab a photo for the gram.*

## *Did I leave out your favorite place to grab a cup?* *Tell me in the comments below!*

# The Absolute Best San Francisco Coffee Shops

Where to find expertly brewed cups of coffee in San Francisco right now

![Paolo Bicchieri](https://platform.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2025/06/Paolo_Bicchieri-520-VoxMedia-ss.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C9.7097028687758%2C100%2C66.70591081091&w=96)

San Francisco is and has been for many the world over the summit of coffee culture. It’s the birthplace of [Wrecking Ball Coffee](https://www.wreckingballcoffee.com), where Trish Rothgeb introduced the “[waves of coffee](https://www.latimes.com/food/story/2019-10-04/third-wave-coffee-trish-rothgeb)” terminology and changed the industry forever. It’s where the West Coast said hello to Yemeni coffee, thanks to hitmakers like the [Tenderloin-born-and-raised](/2022/7/14/23207262/san-francisco-tenderloin-best-coffee-yemeni-mokhtar-alkhanshali) wunderkind [Port of Mokha](https://portofmokha.com) and [late-night cafe](/2022/7/27/23280885/delah-coffee-new-san-francisco-yemeni) trend-setter [Delah Coffee House](https://delahcoffee.com) which started in SoMa. It’s where the [Irish Coffee was born](/2021/12/15/22833162/how-to-make-best-irish-coffee-buena-vista-san-francisco), where many claim Italian espresso culture hit the United States, and where vacuum-sealed coffee was invented. These 16 coffee shops keep the torch burning, making those great ascents into the future.

This time around, Outset Coffee came off the list while Q Specialty Coffee and Hedge Coffee Roasters joined the list.

*— Additional reporting by* [***Dianne de Guzman***](https://www.eater.com/authors/dianne-de-guzman)***.***

[***Paolo Bicchieri***](https://www.eater.com/authors/paolo-bicchieri) *is the associate editor for the Northern California and Pacific Northwest region and has been elbow-deep in the West Coast’s coffee scene since drinking D&M Coffee at that little gas station in Ellensburg, Washington. He thinks a good coffee shop should offer well-sourced beans, lively conversation, and a respite from the world.*

# The Absolute Best San Francisco Coffee Shops

Where to find expertly brewed cups of coffee in San Francisco right now

![Paolo Bicchieri](https://platform.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2025/06/Paolo_Bicchieri-520-VoxMedia-ss.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C9.7097028687758%2C100%2C66.70591081091&w=96)

San Francisco is and has been for many the world over the summit of coffee culture. It’s the birthplace of [Wrecking Ball Coffee](https://www.wreckingballcoffee.com), where Trish Rothgeb introduced the “[waves of coffee](https://www.latimes.com/food/story/2019-10-04/third-wave-coffee-trish-rothgeb)” terminology and changed the industry forever. It’s where the West Coast said hello to Yemeni coffee, thanks to hitmakers like the [Tenderloin-born-and-raised](/2022/7/14/23207262/san-francisco-tenderloin-best-coffee-yemeni-mokhtar-alkhanshali) wunderkind [Port of Mokha](https://portofmokha.com) and [late-night cafe](/2022/7/27/23280885/delah-coffee-new-san-francisco-yemeni) trend-setter [Delah Coffee House](https://delahcoffee.com) which started in SoMa. It’s where the [Irish Coffee was born](/2021/12/15/22833162/how-to-make-best-irish-coffee-buena-vista-san-francisco), where many claim Italian espresso culture hit the United States, and where vacuum-sealed coffee was invented. These 16 coffee shops keep the torch burning, making those great ascents into the future.

This time around, Outset Coffee came off the list while Q Specialty Coffee and Hedge Coffee Roasters joined the list.

*— Additional reporting by* [***Dianne de Guzman***](https://www.eater.com/authors/dianne-de-guzman)***.***

[***Paolo Bicchieri***](https://www.eater.com/authors/paolo-bicchieri) *is the associate editor for the Northern California and Pacific Northwest region and has been elbow-deep in the West Coast’s coffee scene since drinking D&M Coffee at that little gas station in Ellensburg, Washington. He thinks a good coffee shop should offer well-sourced beans, lively conversation, and a respite from the world.*

## Saint Frank Coffee

Saint Frank is to San Francisco coffee as Dungeness crab is to San Francisco restaurants: when the time is right in the city, nothing else will do. Owner and founder Kevin Bohlin’s been on a spree, too, as he opened [choux](/2022/8/30/23329445/saint-frank-opening-juniper-polk) paradise [Juniper](https://www.juniper.cafe/menu) on Polk Street in 2023 and a second San Francisco [Saint Frank location](/2024/1/12/24034881/saint-frank-opening-downtown-mira-east-cut) in SoMa. Longtime fans return for the gorgeous service, minimal aesthetic, and tea-like Bolivian coffees.

![Saint Frank at MIRA shots.](https://platform.sf.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/28/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/25219799/IMG_4170.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C5.5555555555556%2C100%2C88.888888888889&w=2400)
![Saint Frank at MIRA shots.](https://platform.sf.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/28/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/25219799/IMG_4170.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C5.5555555555556%2C100%2C88.888888888889&w=2400)

## Scullery

The Scullery is a little nook of a coffee shop with a smattering of outdoor seating, and the thrum of traffic booming on Geary Street outside. The team at this cafe is tuned into the specialty coffee world, serving East Bay [favorite](/2023/4/4/23669733/mother-tongue-opening-east-bay-coffee-bar) Mother Tongue Coffee and top-tier toast, too. This shop is a favorite example of phenomenal fare and high-end coffee in the Tenderloin.

![Two people at a coffee shop Scullery in San Francisco.](https://platform.sf.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/28/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24647432/TagAlongMokhtarAlkhanshali_PChang_0649_X3.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C0%2C100%2C100&w=2400)

## Sextant Coffee Roasters

Sextant founder Kinani Ahmed works directly with Ethiopian, Kenyan, and Colombian growers, making high-end but affordable [beans to-go](https://sextantcoffee.com/). In this chunk of the city, Sextant is alone in offering terrific coffees and delicious pastries from [Firebrand Artisan Breads](https://www.instagram.com/firebrandbread/). His work — and his [expansion to Valencia Street](/2024/3/15/24102109/sextant-coffee-opening-mission-district-cafe) — is considered by many to be an example of fourth wave coffee, producing communities owning the means of production.

![A latte.](https://platform.sf.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/28/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/24647532/00b0b_hWfZwpz4neh_1200x900_d02bb6af_237a_4328_aae5_0e3f37043f2d.jpeg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C0%2C100%2C100&w=2400)

## Telescope Coffee

If you’re looking for a SoMa coffee shop with some extra oomph (namely, signature drinks that’d be tough to find elsewhere), head over to Telescope Coffee. Not only does this cute shop offer the usual suspects in coffee — espressos, flat whites, lattes, and more — but there are also non-coffee and coffee-adjacent drinks to take on if you’ve reached your caffeine limit. The seasonal latte offerings change, such as a recent honeycomb latte, but the strawberry milk is regular option and comes served in a [cute strawberry-shaped glass](https://www.instagram.com/p/DAT8bAaTpF9/?utm_source=ig_web_copy_link&igsh=MzRlODBiNWFlZA==), a stunner in both tastes and looks.

## Abanico Coffee Roasters

Abanico Coffee Roasters brought [specialty coffee drinks and freshly roasted beans](/2021/5/20/22445160/abanico-new-coffee-shop-opens-mission-san-francisco) to the Mission in 2021. Owner Ana Valle is [originally from El Salvador](/2021/9/13/22644907/san-francisco-central-south-american-restaurants-communities), where she grew up sipping cafecito with her grandmother. Now she’s sweetening cafe con leche with condensed milk and dusting iced cafe de olla with cinnamon in this bright, airy space.

## SPRO - Mission Dolores/Castro

SPRO is known for its playful and inventive coffee drinks. Beyond the usual roster of lattes, mochas, and pour-overs, coffee drinkers can explore options like the Cold Fashioned, which takes cold brew and mixes it with orange bitters and gum syrup, topped with a Luxardo cherry and a flamed orange twist. There are three locations to choose from, including a Mission Bay outpost and a spot in the Tenderloin, along with this location on Church Street.

## Grand Coffee

More than 11 years into its journey, Grand Coffee opened a [second location](/2022/5/5/23058829/grand-coffee-new-location-mission-san-francisco) a block away from its mini cafe on Mission Street. The shop also serves its coffee at the Grove at Yerba Buena and keeps customers [buzzed during Ramadan](/2023/4/3/23668313/ramadan-grand-coffee-mission-district). Located next door to Alamo Drafthouse, the new shop is spacious and bright, and working through a two-person Chemex at the tiled bar is a delight.

![Kimberly Kim, Adrian Lopez, and a few customers at Grand Coffee Too.](https://platform.sf.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/28/chorus/uploads/chorus_asset/file/23633422/PXL_20220616_183733604.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C5.7291666666667%2C100%2C88.541666666667&w=2400)

## Hey Neighbor Cafe

Opened in June 2021 by Dee and their cat [Boots](https://www.instagram.com/p/CVyI-wlg9K1/), this Bayview shop has gained a loyal fanbase for items like the [Hella Black toast](https://www.instagram.com/p/CRCeJ-WLiDr/) on San Francisco bakery Rize Up’s bread and [housemade orange marmalade](https://www.instagram.com/p/CdrC5raPz6N/). Beans come from Monterey’s [Captain + Stoker](https://captainandstoker.com). Plus, it bears repeating, the co-owner is a cat.

## Excelsior Coffee

Lea Sabado and Andre Higgenbotham opened this Excelsior neighborhood shop in 2019 with a [healthy following of motorcycle fans](/2024/7/22/24203633/san-francisco-excelsior-coffee-motorcycle-classic-cars) excited to see a Black and brown-owned business in a [very white coffee scene](https://www.fastcompany.com/90735653/the-unbearable-whiteness-of-coffee). The shop makes a mean [chai](/maps/best-chai-tea-latte-san-francisco), but more relevantly this is the only specialty shop in the area with strong but not overly dark roasts.

## Andytown Coffee Roasters

There are few more charming experiences than seeing how dutifully the city’s west side residents flock to snowy plover-laden Andytown Coffee. The business’s original location was under remodel, a huge [West Belfast sign](https://www.irishecho.com/2023/8/iconic-a-town-leisure-centre-maisign-gets-new-lease-of-life-in-san-francisco-s-andytown) entering the cafe’s new look when it reopened in fall 2023. Importantly, Andytown’s beans are back on track at that first shop, too. While [It’s-It affogatos](/2022/10/6/23391503/andytown-coffee-great-highway) pull in surfers further north, the Lawton Street team are pulling punchy Guatemalan shots of espresso just like the old days.

## Hi NRG

There’s not really anywhere better to drink a Hong Kong-inspired latte than beside a fat throng of stylish young people while a thumping DJ set cavorts through the Saturday morning air. If there is, Hi NRG would have something to say about that. It’s the pop up from Luis Gonzalez and Nathan Kruse, both of whom cut their teeth at the Coffee Movement. The inventive drinks are matched by high-tech gear and infectious warmth from the two owners.

## Paper Son

Alex Pong’s Paper Son pop-up is a crowning achievement in the city’s vast coffee game, merging his [Asian American heritage](/2023/12/12/23998670/paper-son-coffee-san-francisco) with his top-tier espresso and pour-over skills. The espresso passionfruit tonic is a bubbly love letter to the fruit notes coffee snobs love, and Paper Son’s riff on Thai iced tea, the Thai Tea Cloud, is as well-bodied an iteration as they come in San Francisco. The team [opened a second location](/2024/5/9/24152872/paper-son-koolfi-creamery-opening-san-francisco) downtown at 303 Second Street N102 that’s open Monday through Friday, thanks to the city’s [Vacant to Vibrant](https://www.vibrantsf.org/) program.

## Shoji

The new sexy hangout in SoMa is worth headed to for [dinner](/2025/5/13/24426994/shoji-restaurant-opening-san-francisco-fidi-japanese-restaurant), yes. But the first face of the multifaceted gem that is Shoji to [debut](/2025/2/25/24372307/shoji-opening-restaurant-soma-japanese) in the city was its tea and coffee service. It’s absolutely worth the hype: the matcha heads crawl around the corner to get Nekohama unsweetened lattes and einspanners, while coffee lovers can find award-winning barista-founded coffee roaster [MAME](https://mame.coffee) on bar.

![IMG_2933.jpg](https://platform.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2025/03/IMG_2933.jpg.webp?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C16.666666666667%2C100%2C66.666666666667&w=2400)

## Caffe Trieste

Vintage coffee fans must attend to the mosaic tiled tables outside Caffe Trieste. This is indeed one of the touchstones for *Godfather* fans, Francis Ford Coppola making this shop and others throughout North Beach his haunt as he brought the Corleones to the silver screen. The coffee won’t blow your mind; it’s dark as midnight and sweet as sin, as it’s been written. But hearing the faint squawk of a wild parrot while working through a cannoli might be as timeless a San Francisco taste as they come.

![IMG_8102](https://platform.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2017/10/IMG_8102.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C25%2C100%2C50&w=2400)

## The Coffee Movement at Side A

The Coffee Movement has its triumphant summit-like original cafe and the newer Balboa Street location for the cyclists and west side stans. But founders Bryan Overstreet and Reef Bessette linked with Mission District newcomer Side A to provide coffee and [soft serve alongside the restaurant’s doughnuts](/2025/4/25/24416765/san-francisco-coffee-movement-side-a-opening-mission) in the morning. The breezy seating, with a proper bar, provides a somewhat singular cafe experience in the city. Try the lavender ice cream, while it lasts, and settle in for a while — phones discourage.

![Bryan_Overstreet_of_The_Coffee_Movement_credit_Molly_DeCoudreaux.jpg](https://platform.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/2/2025/05/Bryan_Overstreet_of_The_Coffee_Movement_credit_Molly_DeCoudreaux.jpg.webp?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0.51413881748072%2C0%2C98.971722365039%2C100&w=2400)

## Q Specialty Coffee

Laurel Village was once a bustling, energetic part of San Francisco’s mosaic of neighborhoods. In the last however many years, just a big Starbucks and a shotgun-style Peet’s have held it down on the caffeine front. Cyrus Shen saw the opportunity for [a stimulus shot](/restaurant-news/208595/q-specialty-coffee-opening-pac-heights). He went with matcha yuzu drinks, nitro cold brew with passion fruit and lime, and expensive coffees vetted by the Willem Boot camp. Try the espresso cold foam.

![IMG_7836](https://platform.sf.eater.com/wp-content/uploads/sites/28/2025/10/IMG_7836.jpg?quality=90&strip=all&crop=0%2C5.5555555555556%2C100%2C88.888888888889&w=2400)

## Hedge Coffee Roasters

Some cafe openings are flash in the pan, lightning strike hits. Then there are the methodical, many years in the making feats of coffee industry strength. Hedge Coffee Roasters is the latter. Founders Olga Sobal and Alex Sobal, along with partners Xiani Wang and Kyle Bowes, opened their [roasting facility-cafe-Redwood sanctuary](/restaurant-news/208652/hedge-coffee-opening-san-francisco-mission-district-cafe) at long last. Head over for well-executed espresso drinks and pourovers with beans roasted on-site.

# Discovering San Francisco’s very best coffee spots

[Home](https://thecoffeevine.com/) / [Blog](https://thecoffeevine.com/blog/) / [Travel](https://thecoffeevine.com/blog/travel/)

# Discovering San Francisco’s very best coffee spots

From small beachside cafés to large warehouse roasters; fog city reveals its true coffee heart.

**There** is a number of places that have greatly shaped the world of specialty coffee. Many of them are in the US of course but also downunder and in Europe. After visiting Seattle and Portland four years ago and coming face to face with the incredible coffee cultures there, I was super keen to return to the US westcoast to meet San Francisco’s very best coffee roasters during a whirlwind tour of the US and Mexico.

**Shortly** after landing in fog city I set out to get my first caffeine boost of the day that would keep me going for the next 8 hours while I tried to push my body to adjust to the new time zone. My first stop that day was the Blue Bottle shop on Mint Plaza where I grabbed a delicious Flat White to go, which the barista put in my awesome Joco travel mug. This place is pretty impressive to say the least. Located inside a gorgeous building with super high ceilings, Blue Bottle is a magnet for morning coffee junkies and those who appreciate a really special coffee experience. They also serve some pretty delicious looking dishes. I decided to come back again at a different time and enjoy one of their expertly prepared Siphons.

**Later** that day I stumbled upon a brand new café that’s opening its doors any day now. Located on the corner of Kearny and Market street, Mazarine Coffee will most likely become the Financial District’s new hotspot for really awesome coffee. Owned by Hamid Rafati, a successful Silicon Valley entrepreneur and run by a team of super nice and talented coffee peeps including Monica and Jason, Mazarine Coffee will serve Ritual and Klatch Coffee and offer both drip coffee, Espresso specialities prepared with a brand new Kees van der Westen Spirit (probably a very unique sight in this town) as well as great food and other drinks. If you happen to pass them in the next few days you should pop in to say hi. You’ll be one of their first ever customers!

**The** next day I jumped on a local bus to visit Aquiles at Flywheel Coffee Roasters in Haight Ashbury. This legendary area of San Francisco has been home to many characters including Janis Joplin and Charles Manson. Located right next to the Whole Foods Market, Flywheel Coffee Roasters occupies a former bike shop and still retains many of its charming elements. Aquiles and his team focus on great quality coffee that he sources in small batches to ensure it never stays on the shelves longer than ten days. The huge open space is inviting and friendly and the coffee is excellent. I sipped on a mason jar of their cold brew for a good half hour while chatting with Aquiles about his family’s long history in coffee and his own ambition to create something unique for the neighbourhood.

Read our review of [Flywheel Coffee Roasters…](https://thecoffeevine.com/reviews/cafes/usa/sanfrancisco/flywheel-coffee-roasters-san-francisco-us/)

**After** leaving Flywheel Coffee Roasters I jumped back on the 71 bus to head as far West as I had ever been. My destination was Andytown Coffee Roasters, one of the city’s latest arrivals on the coffee scene and probably the furtherst away from the center. I took a short stroll through American suburbia to get to the small corner shop café on Lawton street. This part of town feels so far away from anything you might never even associate with San Fran if it wasn’t for the hills and slightly overcast weather. Lauren and Michael Crabbe, the husband and wife pair behind Andytown Coffee Roasters always wanted to create a homely place that seamlessly integrated into its surroundings. Headbarista and roaster Sandra took great care of me and suggested I try their “snowy plover” specialty drink, which consists of two shots of Espresso, Pellegrino soda water, ice and a dollop of whipped cream. Needless to say I rolled out of there happy and satisfied.

Read our review of [Andytown Coffee Roasters…](https://thecoffeevine.com/reviews/cafes/usa/sanfrancisco/andytown-coffee-roasters-san-francisco-us/)

***“Their commitment to excellent coffee is evident from the first moment and Hein said his buyers spend up to nine months a year traveling the world to seek out the finest coffees.”***

**My** third day in San Francisco started off in my most favourite part of town, The Mission. Matthew Hein, owner of famous roasters Four Barrel was so kind to offer my two friends from Seattle and I a cupping and a little tour around their busy facilities. We couldn’t have wished for a better start into the day. Hein, a ball of energy who made us feel really at home showed us around the fantastic space that Four Barrel occupies, including a little viewing of the ancient Dutch four barrel roaster they still use to make test runs and we joined Taylor and a group of local students for a cupping next door. The set up at Four Barrel is really great. Two barristas operate two Slayers while another drip specialist freshly prepares slow coffee orders on the left side of the space. Their commitment to excellent coffee is evident from the first moment you walk in and Hein said his buyers spend up to nine months a year traveling the world to seek out the finest coffees. Nicaragua only just made its debut in their product pallette because until now they hadn’t found a single finca that could meet their processing standards. Exciting times over on Valencia Street!

Read our review of [Four Barrel Coffee Roasters…](https://thecoffeevine.com/?p=7052)

**Afterwards** we tucked into some delicious carnitas and burritos at Cancun, one of the area’s most famous Mexican joints and then spent a while overlooking San Francisco from Dolores park. If only we could have these views in Amsterdam!

***“This [Sightglass’] incredible space on 7th Street literally blew me away!”***

**Our** next stop on the list was Sightglass Coffee Roasters. These guys have also been around for a few years and recently opened their gorgeous second outlet on 21st Street. This smaller space is beautifully designed and decorated and the guys here were super kind. Especially after it turned out that Peter Smith, Sightglass’ Wholesale Buyer and I had miscommunicated on where we were actually supposed to meet. The peeps at 21st street helped me out to rearrange my appointment and jump into an Uber to be over at the main roastery on 7th street in a flash. This incredible space literally blew me away! A three floor barn like shop with a massive central bar and the huge roastery right at the front. Despite its size it still feels cozy and after finally shaking hands with Peter we sat down at the balcony upstairs from where I had a commanding view of the place. Sightglass, like Four Barrel, have significantly helped to put SF on the coffee map and like Four Barrel, their aim to be purveyors of only the best coffees. I tried their bombastic Owl’s Howl Espresso, which is also incredibly popular amongst their carefully selected partners and which I also got to enjoy as a cold brew in LA a few days later. More on that soon.

Read our review of [Sightglass Coffee Roasters…](https://thecoffeevine.com/?p=7259)

***“[…] Eileen Hassi Rinaldi and her dedicated team started roasting their own coffee on a Stumptown borrowed roaster back in 2006.”***

**The** next morning, San Francisco had a bit of downer in store for us. A huge storm that began to pound the Bay Area over night had caused massive flooding in certain parts, cut power supply to my auberge and surrounding area and massively messed up the flight schedules at four major airports. After finally managing to sorting out my flights and deciding to re-book my trip to LA to the next day, I headed down to Valencia once again to check out the last must-see coffee spot on my list.

Ritual Coffee Roasters, like the previous two, have been around since 2005 and have done great things since Eileen Hassi Rinaldi and her dedicated team started roasting their own coffee on a Stumptown borrowed roaster back in 2006. Now they maintain a few shops around town, with the Valencia flag ship store being the most impressive. Reminicent of a space ship, the huge central bar features two Synesso Espresso machines and a beautiful drip bar, while the back offers a communal table where people can gather to chat and work. Due to my messy morning I had just missed Eileen but then jumped back on the BART to head to the hidden roastery closer to the center to meet with her and share a cuppa Joe. Also here, Ritual’s buyers invest a great amount of time and energy to visit coffee farmers and develop turly outstanding relationships with them to ensure that every year they get better and better coffees.

Read our review of [Ritual Coffee Roasters…](https://thecoffeevine.com/?p=7581)

***“I took a sneaky look to both my left and right and saw gaping mouths all around.”***

**Later** that day I ventured back to my first point of call where Shawna, manager of Blue Bottle Mint Plaza, invited me to join the bar and watch brew master Felix prepare a Siphon. If you’ve never seen this done live, you are in for a real treat and these guys certainly know their stuff. I sat down in between an older lady sipping on her cup of coffee and a tourist from Portugal and all three of us were hypnotized by the fascination that is this unique coffee making device.

Felix explained every step of the way to allow everyone to get a better understanding of their unique process. He used 25g of Blue Bottle’s Suke Quto, Ethiopia and added the freshly ground coffee to the risen near-boiling water. After 35 seconds he broke the crust and after 1:30m he removed the heat source and gently stirred the coffee in order to ensure all grounds are wet but there is no overextraction. Soon after the coffee re-entered the bottom chamber after passing through a cloth filter. I took a sneaky look to both my left and right and saw gaping mouths all around. The coffee we ended up tasting was mind boggling.

**As** my fourth day in the foggy city came to an end I decided to kill off some of the excess caffeine in my blood by taking my friend Mat to the Mikkeler bar on Mason street and indulge in some of the city’s finest craft beers before stuffing our faces with some incredibly delicious Thai food at The Old Siam.

**It** goes without saying that this high adrenaline but incredibly rewarding visit to California’s most beauiful city was a total success. The people I met and the wonderfully warm welcome I got everywhere made me feel more at home here than anywhere else before. And who knows, maybe we got something very special in store for 2015. Keep your eyes on our site for exciting updates.

**What** do you think of the San Francisco coffee scene? What are your favourite places? **Join the conversation!**

# Best Coffee in San Francisco: San Francisco Coffee Shop Roundup

By [Lindsay](https://frugalfrolicker.com/author/lindsay/ "Posts by Lindsay")  on     [California](https://frugalfrolicker.com/destinations/north-america/usa/california/) [USA](https://frugalfrolicker.com/destinations/north-america/usa/)

This post was last updated on 2021 April 17

You know the drill by now. Lindsay visits a new city –> Lindsay samples ALL THE COFFEE.

Upon further reflection, I think I really need to organize my coffee crawls a bit better. I constantly find myself near-force feeding (drinking?) my over-caffeinated self cup after cup of delicious coffee because I CAN’T RESIST. And when I only have a few days in a city, that’s not nearly enough time to thoroughly investigate all of the so-called best coffee.

So I think I need to stagger my coffee intake. Maybe try one cafe in the morning, and one mid-afternoon? Surely this would work better than drinking 3 cups in succession, just because all the good coffee happens to be located right near where I am at a given moment. Yeah… I’ll work on it.

Clearly I had no such strategy when sampling the best coffee in San Francisco. Here are the coffee shops I visited while I was in town last month:

Table of Contents

[Toggle](#)

## Blue Bottle

Ever since my first trip to San Francisco 5 years ago, I’d been lusting for this sensational chicory iced coffee that I enjoyed one time at the Ferry Building. I couldn’t remember the proper name of the drink, nor the cafe where I’d procured it, but it was unlike any other coffee I’d ever had before.

Fast forward a few years and now I’ve got it in my Brooklyn neighborhood! I put 2 and 2 together the first time I sampled [Blue Bottle](http://www.bluebottlecoffee.com/)‘s signature drink, the New Orleans cold brew, at their Williamsburg location:

> Initially conceived as an alternative to the erratically composed and often disappointing iced latte, our New Orleans iced coffee is cold-brewed for 12 hours with roasted chicory and sweetened with organic cane sugar. The end result is a potent concentrate that we cut with organic whole milk. It’s sweet, creamy and, perhaps most importantly, consistently delicious.

Chicory? Check. A San Francisco-based roasting company? Check. I had unknowingly sampled Blue Bottle’s finest 5 years ago before it exploded with full force onto the coffee scene. Though Blue Bottle is old news to me, I couldn’t visit San Francisco and NOT stop by at least once for a New Orleans cold brew. Normally iced coffee is not my go-to, but this one is pretty special. I can confidently report that it tastes equally amazing on both coasts, as it should.

**Recommended Drink:** New Orleans cold brew, or a pourover  
 **Location:** There are 7 locations and counting in SF!

## Reveille

Here’s my story of [Reveille](http://www.reveillecoffee.com/): I woke up one morning, Yelped ‘best coffee in San Francisco’, walked down a really steep hill, and happened upon this wedge-shaped coffee shop. I was instantly won over by the bright sunlight streaming through the windows on both sides of the cafe, and briefly daydreamed about how I’d come here on weekends if I were a local, maybe sit on a stool at the window with my laptop and do some blogging and people watching.

Then I tried a cappuccino and thought SHUT THE FRONT DOOR. This could be my spot! Reveille has some of the best coffee in San Francisco and I’m not over it.

**Recommended Drink:** Cappuccino  
 **Location:** 200 Columbus Ave

## Sightglass Coffee

I stumbled upon the [Sightglass Coffee](https://www.sightglasscoffee.com/) stand while walking behind the Ferry Building one afternoon. I in no way was in need of a caffeine fix, but you know – in the name of research, I felt obligated to try their pourover. It was solid, but not OMG-worthy. On second thought, maybe I should have gone for the Hooker’s Mocha?

**Recommended Drink:** Pourover  
 **Location:** 270 Seventh Street (or they sometimes have a stand behind the Ferry Building)

## Cafe Trieste

I discovered this cafe on my inaugural trip to SF 5 years ago and was delighted to find it just as charming this time around. [Cafe Trieste](http://www.caffetrieste.com/index.htm) is an old school Italian cafe with AMAZING espresso drinks. Really – they are seriously strong and delicious. You won’t find any new-fangled brews or pretension here at this 58-year-old establishment.

In fact, you’re more likely to see small families and older folks hanging out here rather than the hipster faction of the population. It’s a great place to hole up for an afternoon, either reading, working, or listening to the live music or poetry readings. I could easily see myself logging an exorbitant number of hours in this atmospheric cafe if I lived in San Francisco.

**Recommended Drink:** Cappuccino (or any espresso drink)  
 **Location:** 601 Vallejo St

## Ritual

I know [Ritual](http://www.ritualroasters.com/). I like Ritual. Some New York coffee shops brew and sell their beans, but I’d never before experienced Ritual in the flesh. I stopped by their Hayes Valley location, which was more akin to a fancy coffee trailer in a parking lot but no less awesome than their flagship store in the Mission. Definitely order one of the many pourovers they have on offer (it’s what they do best), then take your cup to the park across the street to enjoy in the sun. Best way to start your day, with some of the best coffee in San Francisco!

**Recommended Drink:** Pourover  
 **Location:** 1026 Valencia St (+ a few other locations)

## Coffee Bar

With such a generic name, I was slightly skeptical to venture into [Coffee Bar](http://www.coffeebarsf.com/). And true enough, it’s not the typical third wave artisanal coffee shop I seek out. But I saw past the mod decor, walked straight to the counter, and ordered a Havana Latte without hesitation. What is this, you ask? Well it’s a latte with sweetened condensed milk. DELIGHTFUL.

**Recommended Drink:** Havana Latte  
 **Location:** 433 Kearny (+ 2 other locations)

**Check out my other coffee shop round ups:** [Brooklyn](https://frugalfrolicker.com/north-brooklyn-coffee/) // [Montreal](https://frugalfrolicker.com/montreal-coffee-shops/) // [London](https://frugalfrolicker.com/london-coffee-shops/) // [Sydney](https://frugalfrolicker.com/sydney-coffee-shops/) // [Budapest](https://frugalfrolicker.com/best-coffee-in-budapest/)

**Pin it!**
